title: Margaret Lennan
text:
Margaret Lennan was a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> <a href="snooker">snooker</a> and <a href="English%20billiards">billiards</a> player. She was runner-up in the 1936 <a href="Women%27s%20Professional%20Billiards%20Championship">Women's Professional Billiards Championship</a>.
Biography.
Lennan started playing billiards at the age of 17, and received coaching from Alec Donaldson, father of future world <a href="snooker">snooker</a> champion <a href="Walter%20Donaldson%20%28snooker%20player%29">Walter Donaldson</a>. She won a Ladies Billiards Championship in 1922.
in 1928 she won an unofficial "British Isles Championship" by beating <a href="Joyce%20Gardner">Joyce Gardner</a>, and the following year became the first woman to qualify as a billiards coach.
The <a href="Women%27s%20Billiards%20Association">Women's Billiards Association</a> was formed in 1931, and Lennan was one of four professional players appointed to a committee to organise the professional championships, the others being <a href="Joyce%20Gardner">Joyce Gardner</a>, <a href="Ruth%20Harrison%20%28snooker%20player%29">Ruth Harrison</a> and <a href="Eva%20Collins">Eva Collins</a>.
She played in both <a href="Women%27s%20Professional%20Billiards%20Championship">Women's Professional Billiards Championship</a> and the <a href="Women%27s%20Professional%20Snooker%20Championship">Women's Professional Snooker Championship</a> in the 1930s, reaching the final of the <a href="Women%27s%20Professional%20Billiards%20Championship">Women's Professional Billiards Championship</a> in 1936 and losing 2872–3000 to <a href="Joyce%20Gardner">Joyce Gardner</a>.
Collins was awarded a certificate from the <a href="Billiards%20and%20Snooker%20Control%20Council">Billiards Association and Control Council</a> for the record break by a woman of 176, made on 3 February 1931 and another for her championship record break on 153 in the 1935 <a href="Women%27s%20Professional%20Billiards%20Championship">Women's Professional Billiards Championship</a> This record was superseded by <a href="Ruth%20Harrison%20%28snooker%20player%29">Ruth Harrison's</a> break of 197 in 1937.
Lennan had moved from <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a> to Hillesden, <a href="Prestbury%2C%20Gloucestershire">Prestbury</a>, at the beginning of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, and given up billiards in 1942 due to the pressure of her <a href="World%20War%20II">war</a> work. She said in 1946 that she had taken to playing <a href="golf">golf</a> instead of <a href="English%20billiards">billiards</a>.
